citations.narrative:
There was no official identification for the 7 cats kept at the facility at time of inspection. Official identification is essential
for tracking movement of animals and to facilitate the inspection process. A class “C'' exhibitor shall identify all live dogs
and cats under his or her control or on his or her premises, whether held, purchased, or otherwise acquired by identifying
each dog or cat with an official USDA sequentially numbered tag that is kept on the door of the animal's cage or run.
An official USDA, sequentially numbered tag must be assigned to all dogs or cats held on the premises. This tag must be
affixed to the animal’s cage or run and moved whenever the animal is moved to a different cage or run.
Correct by 03/10/2025.

In the backyard dog enclosure next to a gate were sections of loosely connected ¾ inch wire mesh lying exposed on the
ground with some having sharp, pointed wire ends. There was an approximately 2ft wide, dog-accessible space between
the side of a tent structure and the back wall of the facility. On the ground within this space were several sections of ¾
inch wire meshing and an approximately 1ft deep and 1ft wide hole in the ground. Some of the wire meshing next to the
hole was loose, overlapping and had exposed and sharp, pointed ends. Dogs could possibly become caught or trapped in
loose wiring or become injured from sharp, protruding wire ends or from holes in the ground. All housing facilities and
animal areas must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely and
restrict other animals from entering. A system of timely identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place.
Correct by 03/03/2025.

The facility has not been following the attending veterinarian’s approved schedule for the vaccinations and sampling for
parasites and other pests for dogs. According to the Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) for Dogs, parvo and distemper
vaccinations are to be administered every 3 years or have adequate titers. Also, the PVC states that a heartworm
screening and a fecal screening will be performed on one representative of the population on an annual basis. Records
show 10 of the 14 dogs are overdue since September 2024 for parvo and distemper vaccinations. Additionally, it has
been over a year since the last heartworm and fecal screening was performed on 01/02/2024. Failure to vaccinate dogs
for deadly and contagious diseases and to conduct sampling and treatment for parasites and other pests in accordance
with the attending veterinarians approved schedule can expose the animals to increased disease risk and can delay
treatment. The licensee must ensure that vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies,
parvovirus, and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia,
giardia, and heartworm) are followed in accordance with the schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 03/17/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
